model.name: Barcelona
model.description: All great cities are united by one thing: a deep sense of cultural identity. And for all its utter Spanishness, Barcelona is first and foremost the capital of Catalonia, a proudly autonomous region of Spain that has repeatedly attempted to secede and become its own nation. You’ll hear Catalan spoken in the streets, and see the artistic endeavors of the region’s dynamic and sometimes surrealistic figures such as Miro and Gaudi in museums and along the buildings of the Passeig de Gràcia. Long known for its later-than-late nightlife, Barcelona has in recent years earned a reputation as a party town. But for us, the city will always be known for its more tranquil pleasures: a stroll along the narrow lanes of its Gothic quarter (one of the largest in Europe); its excellent ham-heavy food; the riveting people-watching you can indulge in from one of its many sidewalk cafes. Because it’s not just the city’s sights you’ll fall in love with—it’s its very way of life.

model.dontMiss:
###FYI###  


As of mid-December [Uber is banned in Spain](http://mobile.nytimes.com/blogs/bits/2014/12/31/uber-suspends-operations-in-spain/), but you shouldn't have a hard time hailing a cab in the city — they're plentiful and seemingly always there when you need one (they're painted yellow and black, FYI). 


###Stay###


[#hotel: /hotels/54934f48555714a72b32e3bb]|||
The [Praktik Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/barcelona/hotel-praktik) has opened its latest design boutique hotel and wine bar near Rambla Cataluña and the famous Paseo de Gracia. 
|||


###Drink###  


[#restaurant: /restaurants/54935253ece808e916c32b7b]|||
The place to eat and drink right now in Barcelona is the newly opened [El Nacional](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/barcelona/el-nacional) just off Passeig de Gràcia. Its four bars and four restaurants can  accommodate more than 700, but don't let it's massive size turn you off. The Great Gatsby-esque, art deco interior is not to be missed. Stop in for tapas and cervesa.  
|||

pinterest.dek: Sangria, shellfish, and triumphs of modern architecture—what's not to like?
pinterest.seoTitle: 9 Best Places to Visit in Barcelona
pinterest.seoDescription: Sangria, shellfish, and triumphs in modern architecture—what's not to like?
pinterest.socialTitle: 9 Best Places to Visit in Barcelona
pinterest.socialDescription: Sangria, shellfish, and triumphs in modern architecture—what's not to like?

items.title: [Casa Batlló](http://www.casabatllo.es/en/)
items.caption: Throw a stone in Barcelona, and chances are you'll hit something designed by Antoni Gaudí. Not that we would endorse throwing stones at modern architectural marvels, but the fact remains: it's more or less impossible to take in the sights in this city without it somehow involving Gaudí. Casa Batlló serves as the ideal crash course in the designer's oeuvre.

Casa Batlló was built between 1904 and 1906, and it’s the perfect example of Gaudí’s imaginative aesthetic. The colorful windows and sculptured ceilings give the house’s entrance a unique underwater feel, while the wavy walls, mosaics, and scale-like roof define the exterior. Visitors can stop by Casa Batlló any day of the year, from 9 AM to 9 PM (tickets available at [casabatllo.es](http://www.casabatllo.es/en/online-tickets/)).

items.title: [Park Güell](http://www.parkguell.cat/en/)
items.caption: If you have a free afternoon, we recommend making your way over to Park Güell after visiting Casa Batlló. Remember what we said about Gaudí being an inevitability in Barcelona? Prepare for a continuation in your world-class architecture crash course—he designed the mosaic-filled park, too.

Gaudí was heavily inspired by organic shapes and nature as he designed the park—just check out the giant salamander perched at the entrance. We suggest having Instagram at the ready to snap shots of everything this World Heritage Site has to offer, including the salmon-pink [Gaudí House Museum](http://www.casamuseugaudi.org/cm-eng/index.php).

items.title: [Papabubble](http://www.papabubble.com/)
items.caption: There's something about a trip to Papabubble that turns us into kids in a candy store––namely because, well, we are. Aside from offering treats in just about every flavor imaginable, the two Barcelona locations (one in the Gothic Quarter and one in Sarrià) also offer live candy shows, where you can see the magic-making process in person. So definitely stop by and pick up some sweet (pardon the pun) souvenirs to take back home with you.

items.title: El Born District
items.caption: The lower section of the La Ribera district, better known to the locals as El Born, is home to some of the best shopping and boutiques in the city. It's also home to your choice of incredibly fresh mojitos and very cheap, very delicious pizza. Once you've had your fill of modernist architecture, we recommend heading to El Born to view the lovely (and refreshingly simple) apartment fronts, shop all day, stay out all night, and grab a slice before finally going home.

items.title: [Museu Picasso](http://www.museupicasso.bcn.cat/en/)
items.caption: Housed in a series of gorgeous Medieval palaces in La Ribera, the eponymous Museu Picasso explores not only the life and career of Pablo, but also his time in Barcelona and the city's influence on his work. We're going to go out on a limb here and call this one a must-see. Check out the [museum’s website](http://www.bcn.cat/museupicasso/en/museum/times.html) for hours and ticket prices.

items.title: [W Barcelona](http://www.w-barcelona.com/)
items.caption: We'll be straight up: nothing quite compares to the beachfront view of the W Barcelona. Located right along the La Barceloneta boardwalk, you can step right outside the hotel, lounge on the famous Barcelona beach, and then explore the restaurants and clubs that are just steps away.

But really, there’s not much need to even leave the hotel at all. Once it's registered that, yes, you get to call this place home for the next few days, take advantage of their Michelin-starred chef's Bravo24 or take a dip in their Wet Deck pool, cocktail in hand.

items.title: [Fundació Joan Miró](http://www.fundaciomiro-bcn.org/?idioma=2)
items.caption: You can always brush up on your knowledge of the Surrealist movement at the [Dalí Theatre-Museum](http://www.salvador-dali.org/museus/teatre-museu-dali/en_index/), but what if you want to learn about the movement beyond the mustachioed genius? Pay a visit to Fundació Joan Miró, a Josep Lluís Sert-designed museum housed in Montjuïc.

While the space is primarily dedicated to the works of Joan Miró, the museum (an architectural gem in and of itself) is in no way exclusive. Keep your eye out for work by the likes of Magritte and Rothko, as well as special exhibitions dedicated to contemporary artists. Visit the [museum’s website](http://www.fundaciomiro-bcn.org/horari.php?idioma=2) for hours and ticket prices.

items.title: [Terraza Martinez](http://www.martinezbarcelona.com/)
items.caption: When in Spain, do as the Spanish do and partake heavily in authentic sangria and fresh, local seafood. Terraza Martinez is just the spot to do both––we especially like the cured tuna carpaccio, oysters, burrata, and rice dishes. The open terrace and unobstructed views of Barcelona are a lovely added bonus.

items.title: [La Sagrada Familia](http://www.sagradafamilia.cat/sf-eng/)
items.caption: Yup, it’s that Gaudí guy again. La Sagrada Familia is one of, if not THE most popular tourist attraction in the city, and it’s not hard to see why. Our advice for your visit: look up.

Aside from being one of the tallest churches in the world, with spires casting shadows on the city below, La Sagrada Familia’s interior is filled with stained glass and treelike columns that are worth witnessing (just be prepared to pay an [entrance fee](http://visit.sagradafamilia.cat/?lang=en)).

Would you believe us if we told you that his magnum opus is still a work in progress? One that isn't due to see completion until 2026, almost 100 years after his death? Keep in mind that when we say "work in progress," it's slightly different than that Ikea table that's been strewn across your living room floor, half-assembled, for a handful of days. Instead, the construction of this Catholic church was slowed by the impending Spanish Civil War, not just frustration and impossible-to-understand directions.

fields.name: The Coveteur
fields.shortBio: [The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture.
fields.bio:
[The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture. With an emphasis on highly personalized curation, The Coveteur goes one step further in examining the creative process, inspiration and influence of the individuals who are defining the zeitgeist of our times.

Founded by Stephanie Mark and Jake Rosenberg in 2011, The Coveteur pulls back the curtain on heretofore unseen adventures in style, travel, arts and culture and exposes what you’ve always wanted to see: an intimate and voyeuristic look at today's influencers.

pinterest.hed: AOO: Barcelona's Most Charming Design Store
pinterest.dek: Nestled between Barcelona’s hip Gracia neighborhood and its tony shopping avenue Paseo de Gracia is a small street called Sèneca that’s becoming something of a mini design destination. In addition to the gallery Miquel Alzueta, the vintage furniture shop OX, and the tailormade shoe salon Cuervo, it’s home to the city’s most charming contemporary design store: [AOO](http://cntraveler.com/shops/barcelona/aoo). Here's a look inside.

items.caption: Opened last fall by furniture designer Marc Morro, creative director Oriol Villar, and graphic designer Clara Quintana, [AOO](http://cntraveler.com/shops/barcelona/aoo) offers both an in-house collection of pared-back wood furnishings and a selection of obscure everyday objects sourced by Morro, like artisanal Japanese kitchen tools and a set of knives from a small village in Mallorca. In addition, the AOO team cherry-picks relevant housewares from established design brands like Hay and Another Country that aren’t sold elsewhere in Barcelona. It all falls under the shop’s playful mission statement, to be “a place where you can easily find things that are hard to find.”

Inside AOO, furniture and housewares are artfully stacked on stepped platforms and one another. All of the wooden furniture pictured here belongs to the store’s own collection — which is designed and made in house — while the accessories span everything from Weck jars, to baskets and tea strainers made by an artisan in Kyoto, to the yellow stool at center, which is by the London designer Martino Gamper.
The entrance to AOO, which is housed in a small former garage on Barcelona’s Sèneca street. The shop was designed by the local architecture firm Arquitectura-G.

Among the offerings in AOO’s spartan in-house furniture collection is the Cadireta chair, whose name means “little chair” in Catalan. Morro not only designed the low-slung seat, but crafts them himself out of pine in AOO’s wood workshop, which is located in Barcelona’s industrial Poblenou neighborhood.

Morro also makes the store’s Tripos stools, which come in pine, beech, or oak and are pictured here in AOO’s workshop. (He happens to be something of a stool aficionado, in fact — he has a collection of more than 25 different stools at home.)

The Tripos stools on display at AOO, along with Enzo Mari’s classic Formosa calendar, a series of orange chairs designed by Arquitectura-G, and another wood stool, in the upper left corner, that was designed by Morro and featured in the Spanish Pavilion at the 2014 Venice Architecture Biennale.

The store has several cabinets that feature all kinds of small design items and everyday objects that the AOO team happens to love: bowls by the Viennese design duo Mischer-Traxler, a wooden computer keyboard by Orée, the Mallorcan knives, pepper grinders by Ettore Sottsass, and below them, dishes by the UK heritage brand Falcon Enamelware.

The store has several cabinets that feature all kinds of small design items and everyday objects that the AOO team happens to love: bowls by the Viennese design duo Mischer-Traxler, a wooden computer keyboard by Orée, the Mallorcan knives, pepper grinders by Ettore Sottsass, and below them, dishes by the UK heritage brand Falcon Enamelware.
The AOO team recently reissued another of Milá’s classic designs themselves: the wicker Salvador chair, which is now produced for the store by hand in a workshop in Valencia.

The Pepitu is a classic folding chair designed by Morro and named after Villar’s grandfather, a carpenter who once made seats similar to this one. AOO’s version is made of beechwood and a linen fabric sourced from a small textile workshop in Mallorca, where Morro is from.

The store’s Normales collection is a series of basics made from pine plywood: storage bins, a small shelf, a tool caddy, a cord manager, and a box that can be used as either a stool, an ottoman, or a side table depending on one’s needs.
Quintana and Morro in front of AOO.

pinterest.hed: The One Drink to Have in Barcelona
pinterest.dek: You can’t leave Barcelona without trying this traditional beverage. Plus: how to order, how to pay, and local etiquette tips.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/54170afa17e4b1f634ef049d]||||||


##Don’t leave Barcelona without trying…
*Vermut.* Sure, you’re familiar with the dry vermouth (in Catalan: *vermut*) of the classic martini cocktail, but did you know that in many European countries, it's served as a standalone libation? Vermut is a fortified, aromatic wine with a bitter aftertaste usually produced in three varieties: red, white, and rosé. Catalan vermut has notes of herbs and spices (think rosemary and orange—in fact, each producer uses its own secret concoction); and although its reputation there is as the drink of choice for Catalan grandfather-types, vermut is making a comeback among the young and trendy in Barcelona.

##Where to drink it
Traditionally, vermut is served in *bodegues* (Catalan *tavernas*) where it’s stored in wooden barrels, though ever since the recent vermut renaissance, it’s easy to find it in most cocktail bars as well. Vermut is normally served chilled with one or two ice cubes and garnished with an anchovy-stuffed olive. Some prefer it chilled without ice and garnished with an orange slice (red vermut) or a lemon slice (white vermut). Some even prefer to dilute it with soda water, so don’t be surprised if the waiter serves your vermut along with an old-fashioned soda siphon.

##When to drink it
Catalans drink vermut all year long, usually as an aperitif before lunch, but also in the late afternoon or even evening.

##How to order
Say: “*Em poses un vermut, si us plau?*” (Catalan for “Could you serve me a vermouth, please?”). The waiter or bartender should answer: “*Blanc, negre, o rosat?*” (White, red, or rosé?).

##How to pay
Normally you’ll pay when you are ready to leave. You can leave a small tip. Most bar-goers simply round up to the nearest euro and leave the change at the table.

##Local tip
Though it is now available in many cocktail bars, stick with the bodegues to enjoy the vermut on tap. Save the bottled vermut for drinking at home. If you do want to purchase a bottle in Barcelona, try to find something from local producers like Yzaguirre, Espinaler, or Miró. 

##Etiquette tips
__Don’t__ order a vermut late at night. This really is an aperitif and you’d most certainly be the recipient of strange looks.

__Do__ enjoy your vermut on an outdoor terrace with some [anchovies, olives, and almonds](http://www.contexttravel.com/city/barcelona/walking-tour-details/pica-pica-in-poble-sec-tapas-walk).

pinterest.hed: How Not to Look Like a Tourist In Barcelona
pinterest.dek: Whether you're visiting Barcelona for the first time or you're a seasoned traveler, these tips will prove helpful when trying to blend in with the locals.
pinterest.seoTitle: How Not to Look Like a Tourist In Barcelona
pinterest.seoDescription: Whether you're visiting Barcelona for the first time or you're a seasoned traveler, these tips will prove helpful when trying to blend in with the locals.
pinterest.socialTitle: How Not to Look Like a Tourist In Barcelona
pinterest.socialDescription: Whether you're visiting Barcelona for the first time or you're a seasoned traveler, these tips will prove helpful when trying to blend in with the locals.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/546a53b02a3d21fa285c706f]||||||



##How to greet someone

Friends and family will kiss each other hello and goodbye, but don’t greet a stranger like that; rather, a simple *hola* will suffice for acknowledging others like shopkeepers. According to Anne Jordan, Context culinary docent and Barcelona local, Catalans don’t always bother with elaborately polite phrases, though a *gràcies* (thank you) is always appreciated. You will likely hear Catalan spoken everywhere, but if all you are working with is some rusty (Castilian) Spanish, you will be understood.

##What to wear

Barcelona is more casual than cities like Milan or Paris, but that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t dress to impress. For cold-weather travel, pack scarves, blazers, and ankle boots. It goes without saying that you should avoid fanny packs and other items that scream tourist—doing so will make you less of a target for the city’s pickpockets, who are abundant in certain areas (like Las Ramblas). 

In the warmer months, absolutely do not wear a bathing suit or flip-flops off the beach. Doing so will pretty much immediately identify you as an out-of-towner. Even shorts off the beach are a rare site, though this is changing among the city’s younger and fashionable residents.


##Where to hang out

Speaking of beaches, it’s worth noting that most locals do not spend their time on Barcelona’s municipal beaches. Nor do locals spend time on Las Ramblas, which is like the Champs Elysées of Barcelona. For some peace and local quiet, head instead to a residential neighborhood like Gràcia for its great squares, food markets and restaurants. If it's sun and sand you’re looking for, head outside of the city.

##What to eat

Many traveling to Spain think of paella, a rice dish often mixed with shellfish; however, paella is actually traditional to neighboring Valencia. If you want to taste something with a more Catalan flair (and do like the Catalans do), order a local dish like *esqueixada,* a simple salad of hand-shredded salt cod, tomatoes, onions, olive oil, vinegar, and salt. It is customarily served in the summer.

Like the rest of Spain, Catalans typically eat on the later side. Plan to have lunch around 2 p.m. and dinner around 10 p.m.


##Do's and don'ts

__Do__ bring your own bags to shop in the market or supermarket.

__Don’t__ have tapas for dinner. Tapas are generally meant to be a pre-meal snack.

__Don’t__ wear a Barça jersey except on a day where there's a game (unless if you’re under 10 years old).

eat.dek: After closing El Bulli, Albert and Ferran Adrià opened Barcelona restaurant Tickets. To give you a taste of what you could be eating tonight, Chef Albert shares the secrets behind some of the tapas dishes.
eat.hed: What's for Dinner at Albert and Ferran Adrià's Tickets

items.title: El Bosque Animado
items.caption:
"Mushrooms made with a yuzu meringue, green pistachio 'sponges' prepared in a microwave, lemon yogurt, yuzu, bits of chocolate, wild strawberries, and coconut sorbet.




Desserts are very important at the restaurant. In this case we made fun of ourselves, with an infantile adaptation of one of the desserts on the menu at El Bulli, which we originally created for our book _Nature." _

items.title: Las Navajas a la Parrilla
items.caption:
"The clams are washed, sealed in a vacuum, and cooked for four to six minutes depending on their thickness. They are then placed in ice water, opened, the stomach is removed and they are sliced in to small bite-sized bits. They are then grilled and seasoned with a sauce made of very finely chopped garlic and ginger, white wine, and olive oil. As soon as the sauce begins to boil, they are removed from the heat and finished with a touch of lemon and a little chili.




Once again, we were inspired by traditional flavors with our own personal touch while rediscovering ingredients, like ginger, used in traditional Catalan cooking.




The cuisine at Tickets is straight-forward and inspired at its roots by traditional Spanish cooking; even if the techniques are modern, they are always at the service of the ingredient, and the ingredients are about pure basic flavors that are familiar.




Perhaps what surprises our guests the most is the intensity and purity of the flavors. It’s something we work very hard at."

items.title: Mollete
items.caption:
"This is a steamed bread that we make at Tickets, stuffed with a mixture of pancetta and pig’s jowls cooked at a low temperature until it’s very sweet. At the moment when the bread is ready, it is stuffed with pieces of buffalo mozzarella, the pancetta, the pig’s jowls, and a little mustard, and then it is grilled.




It is an adaptation of a traditional Andalucian recipe, _los molletes, _which consists of a white bread filled with various stuffings."

items.title: Huevos 1.40
items.caption:
"The quail’s eggs are cooked for 1 minute and 40 seconds so that the yolk remains raw. They are then submerged in oil and covered in bread crumbs that have been mixed in an _almogrote_ sauce that is typical of the Canary Islands and includes oil, vinegar, garlic, ñora peppers, cumin, salt, and cheese.




The adaptation of these traditional techniques, like the bread crumbs and the _almogrote_ sauce, lets us give a new 'shell' to the egg."

items.title: Miniairbag
items.caption:
"Pizza dough is cut into five-centimeter circles and baked until puffy and crunchy. Then a small hole is made and the dough is filled with a mousse of Manchego cheese and it’s then covered with a layer of the same cheese and a layer of wood-oven-roasted hazelnuts, caviar made from hazelnut oil, and lemon thyme.







The dish evokes, in an entertaining and contemporary way, the traditional flavors of a Manchego cheese toast. The flavors of hazelnut and thyme are flavors that can also be found in certain cheeses."

items.title: Las Olivas
items.caption:
"This dish is prepared by submerging the juice of olives in a water bath and with an algae called alginate. The combinaton of the algae with the calcium in the olive juice leads to a reaction in which the juice becomes a soft sphere. The technique is adapted from an industrial process and was first tried at El Bulli in 2001. Once the sphere has been made, it’s marinated with garlic that has been sautéed till lightly brown, thyme, rosemary, and lemon and orange peel.







What’s surprising is the texture. The flavor and the preparation are totally natural. It recalls marinated olives."

eat.hed: The One Drink to Have in Barcelona
eat.dek: You can’t leave Barcelona without trying this traditional beverage. Plus: how to order, how to pay, and local etiquette tips.
eat.body:
[#image: /photos/54170afa17e4b1f634ef049d]||||||


##Don’t leave Barcelona without trying…
*Vermut.* Sure, you’re familiar with the dry vermouth (in Catalan: *vermut*) of the classic martini cocktail, but did you know that in many European countries, it's served as a standalone libation? Vermut is a fortified, aromatic wine with a bitter aftertaste usually produced in three varieties: red, white, and rosé. Catalan vermut has notes of herbs and spices (think rosemary and orange—in fact, each producer uses its own secret concoction); and although its reputation there is as the drink of choice for Catalan grandfather-types, vermut is making a comeback among the young and trendy in Barcelona.

##Where to drink it
Traditionally, vermut is served in *bodegues* (Catalan *tavernas*) where it’s stored in wooden barrels, though ever since the recent vermut renaissance, it’s easy to find it in most cocktail bars as well. Vermut is normally served chilled with one or two ice cubes and garnished with an anchovy-stuffed olive. Some prefer it chilled without ice and garnished with an orange slice (red vermut) or a lemon slice (white vermut). Some even prefer to dilute it with soda water, so don’t be surprised if the waiter serves your vermut along with an old-fashioned soda siphon.

##When to drink it
Catalans drink vermut all year long, usually as an aperitif before lunch, but also in the late afternoon or even evening.

##How to order
Say: “*Em poses un vermut, si us plau?*” (Catalan for “Could you serve me a vermouth, please?”). The waiter or bartender should answer: “*Blanc, negre, o rosat?*” (White, red, or rosé?).

##How to pay
Normally you’ll pay when you are ready to leave. You can leave a small tip. Most bar-goers simply round up to the nearest euro and leave the change at the table.

##Local tip
Though it is now available in many cocktail bars, stick with the bodegues to enjoy the vermut on tap. Save the bottled vermut for drinking at home. If you do want to purchase a bottle in Barcelona, try to find something from local producers like Yzaguirre, Espinaler, or Miró. 

##Etiquette tips
__Don’t__ order a vermut late at night. This really is an aperitif and you’d most certainly be the recipient of strange looks.

__Do__ enjoy your vermut on an outdoor terrace with some [anchovies, olives, and almonds](http://www.contexttravel.com/city/barcelona/walking-tour-details/pica-pica-in-poble-sec-tapas-walk).

fields.bio: Sara McCarty is the France & Spain Manager at Context Travel. Context is a network of scholars and specialists—in disciplines including archaeology, art history, cuisine, urban planning, history, environmental science, and classics—who, in addition to our normal work as professors and researchers, design and lead in-depth walking seminars for small groups of intellectually curious travelers. The Context vision is to bring together  local scholars and specialists with curious travelers to educate and impassion them; to allow them access to places and cultures that might otherwise remain out of site to the casual visitor; to invite them off the tourist track and into the real life of the people, history, and culture that makes these cities, destinations.

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d41f6dec627b149d9466]|||The "Guacadog" from The Dog is Hot in Barcelona|||

In a country celebrated for its _jamón_ and suckling pig, the idea of eating vegetarian seems almost outrageous. And yet, vegetarian culture is on the rise in Barcelona. I grew up macrobiotic and, along with my [Context Travel](http://www.cntraveler.com/contributors/context-travel) colleague in Barcelona, Lily Heise, still maintain a vegetarian lifestyle. On a recent night out together we were astounded at the growing list of vegetarian options, from the uber-casual to the gourmet. Here are our top five veggie spots in the city.










##### La Bascula


Tucked away in the medieval alleyways of El Born lies **1** this surprisingly spacious café. Cooperative-run La Bascula uses all organic ingredients in its fresh juices, hearty meals (Lily and I loved the seitan), and homemade desserts. It’s also committed to sustainable dining–even the plates and utensils are bio-degradable. Community tables (made from repurposed doors) give a casual and friendly ambiance. Ironically, the restaurant occupies a former candy factory. _Carrer del Flassaders, 30 bis_










##### [Vegetalia](http://www.restaurantvegetalia.com/)


**2** [Vegetalia](http://www.restaurantvegetalia.com/) is a calm respite in the heart of the bustling Barrio Gòtic. Try the smoked tofu tempura and vegetable paella, or for something quicker opt for a freshly made smoothie on the terrace. The restaurant uses organic ingredients where possible, including some grown in its own private garden. Great for lunch, Vegetalia is not to be confused with its neighbor a few doors down, Gopal, which serves veggie fare of the fast-food (and sub-par) variety. _Carrer dels Escudellers, 54_










##### [Teresa Carles](http://www.teresacarles.com/)


Our favorite, **3** [Teresa Carles](http://www.teresacarles.com/), founded in 1979, has just the type of sophisticated vegetarian cuisine one might find in New York. Indeed, with its clean and chic interior (exposed brick and natural wood tables) it’s easy to forget we’re on a narrow street just off La Rambla. The restaurant has an extensive menu of meat-, dairy-, and gluten-free options that would please even the most intense carnivores. We particularly loved the homemade burger; and we weren't the only ones—the lunch line was out the door. We can’t wait to go back for dinner. _Carrer de Jovellanos, 2_










##### Sesamo


**4** Sesamo is a charming and well-reviewed restaurant offering modern vegetarian cuisine. Owner and head chef Alfredo, originally from Argentina, has been living in Barcelona for more than a decade. Not surprisingly, his creations are inspired by culinary traditions from around the world. The restaurant is intimate with an extremely friendly staff: Alfredo is known for coming out to chat and happily accommodates vegan clients. The tasting menu is a must, as are reservations at dinner. _Carrer Sant Antoni Abat, 52_










##### [The Dog is Hot](http://www.thedogishot.com/)


Though by no means a fully vegetarian restaurant, **5** [this cool hot dog joint](http://www.thedogishot.com/) offers the choice of a meat or tofu dog and is a fun possibility for vegetarians on the go, especially those traveling with carnivorous companions. Select from a multitude of pre-designed combinations–we liked the “Guaca Dog” with guacamole, cheese and onion. A word from the wise: Be prepared to get messy; toppings are shoveled on and there are not proper tables._ Carrer Joaquin Costa, 47_

 View [A Guide to Vegetarian Restaurants in Barcelona](https://www.google.com/maps/ms?msa=0&msid=216498248091250582578.0004d4e86958109d4212b&ie=UTF8&t=m&ll=41.382605,2.173276&spn=0.016358,0.021758&z=15&source=embed) in a larger map

Context is a network of scholars and specialists—in disciplines including archaeology, art history, cuisine, urban planning, history, environmental science, and classics—who, in addition to our normal work as professors and researchers, design and lead in-depth walking seminars for small groups of intellectually curious travelers. The Context vision is to bring together  local scholars and specialists with curious travelers to educate and impassion them; to allow them access to places and cultures that might otherwise remain out of site to the casual visitor; to invite them off the tourist track and into the real life of the people, history, and culture that makes these cities, destinations.

featuredPlays.name: Sinagoga Major de Barcelona
featuredPlays.description: This was the site of Barcelona's most important Jewish synagogue from the tenth through the fourteenth centuries, which lay abandoned and filled with rubble for six hundred years thereafter, and which has been recovered and restored. It is located at the heart of what was the medieval Jewish ghetto. Call for opening hours.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: The city's most important Jewish site.

featuredPlays.name: Museu d'Història de la Ciutat
featuredPlays.description: A fascinating reconstruction of a part of Barcino, Roman Barcelona. Tucked away in a quiet square behind the cathedral, the Museu d'Historia de la Ciutat takes you right down to the Roman foundations of the city dating from the first century B.C. The exhibition route takes you to various parts of the Royal Palace, the residence of the Kings of Aragon in the Middle Ages when the Catalan-Aragonese maritime empire stretched to Sicily, past 13th-century wall paintings and a 15th-century model of the city. Check the website for opening times.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Peek inside the nearly-gone Roman Barcelona.

featuredPlays.name: Plaça Sant Jaume
featuredPlays.description: This big, open square was the center of Roman Barcelona—Barcino—and has been the heart of the city since the Middle Ages. On opposite sides of the square are City Hall, dating from the 14th century, and the Generalitat, the seat of Catalan government, built in the 15th century. The plaza is, naturally, a favorite place for protests, and hardly a day goes by without one here.

featuredPlays.name: Barceloneta
featuredPlays.description: This neighborhood by the Barcelona port was developed in the 18th century for city residents displaced by the construction of the nearby Ciudadela fortress. Wander its grid-like byways, keeping an eye out for the remaining two-story houses that originally lined its streets; or walk along the seaside promenade to admire the sculptures scattered along the beach.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Even beaches here are art destinations.

featuredPlays.name: El Jazz Si Club
featuredPlays.description: Over the past decade, Barcelona has become an important center of jazz, with a lively exchange between North American music schools like Julliard and Berklee, and young Catalan jazz players. The results of this fruitful exchange can be heard in this small club where the city's best unknown players come to jam on Saturday nights. Fridays is flamenco night and Thursdays is for Cuban rhythms.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: The center of the emerging jazz scene.

cheatSheet.dek: Between the beach and the bar, some of the city's finest art is right outside.

items.dek: The best of this truly Catalan artist.
Paying tribute to every element of Barcelona style.
It's the city's most famous attraction, and you'll see why.
How to see the best street art in town.
Focusing on mid-century abstraction and Pop Art.
Get your introduction to Gaudí here.

cheatSheet.dek: From food stalls to fine dining.

The best place to meet a friend for drinks.
Michelin-starred sibling of a Costa Brava favorite.
The best sweets in town are made by nuns.

cheatSheet.dek: What to do in Barcelona's coolest quarter.

items.dek: A gorgeous building (with perfect acoustics, of course).
Study Catalan history with cafe con leche in hand.
Tapas bar with its own champagne brand.
A parish church with a Gothic sensibility.
An in-depth look at the legendary artist.
The Spanish response to Paris's monument.

featuredEats.name: Taktika Berri
featuredEats.description: One of the city's best Basque restaurants. You can eat tapas at the bar—at which the Basques excel—or sit down to a full-size meal if you've reserved one of the tables, which are always full. The cod cheeks in batter, or the cod omlette are good examples of why Basque chefs are particularly fond of this fish. The bar is a favorite after-work spot for young office workers in the Eixample neighborhood.
featuredEats.shortDescription: A Basque gem heavy on codfish.

featuredEats.name: Arola
featuredEats.description: Sergi Arola's two-Michelin-starred restaurant, La Broche, transformed the gastronomic life of Madrid and this is his Barcelona venture. Housed in the same building as the Hotel Arts, Arola is a much more relaxed affair than La Broche. Fashion victims salivate over the setting while their gastronomic friends admire the extraordinary menu with its thoroughly modern tapas-like dishes for grazing. Designer snacks are the order of the day—mix and match at will—but don't overlook the more substantial offerings such as arroz guisado con pichón (rice with pigeon) and salt cod confit with pil-pil of peas.
featuredEats.shortDescription: "Designer snacks" on offer at this upscale haunt.

featuredEats.name: Fábrica Moritz Barcelona
featuredEats.description: Moritz is an old name among Barcelona breweries, that dispapeared for a while and is now back. The prize-winning French architect Jean Nouvel renovated their old brewery in a Modernist building from the 19th century. There's a restaurant with more than 300 dishes on the menu, both traditional Catalan fare like escalivada, grilled red pepper, onion, and eggplant served with an anchovy, and German/Austrian dishes like Pfaffenhofen: potatoes with bacon, melted cheese, and black pepper.
featuredEats.cuisine: Local or Regional, German, Austrian, or Swiss
featuredEats.shortDescription: A brewery with top-notch bar bites.

featuredEats.name: Eat Street Nadal
featuredEats.description: The first Christmas street food festival in Barcelona, Eat Street Nadal, lines the streets of Glòries on December 20th and 21st. You’ll find gourmet fare from around the world served from the best-known food trucks from around Catalunya.
featuredEats.shortDescription: A Christmas market full of street eats.

featuredEats.name: Comerc 24
featuredEats.description: Chef Carles Abellan, a disciple of El Bulli's Ferran Adrià, is another proponent of the new wave of Catalan cuisine. The restaurant offers taster menus with tapas-sized portions, although the menu changes constantly, dishes include his famous 'Kinder Egg', an eggshell filled with truffles, potatoes, and a three-minute egg, or curry-scented banana soup. The restaurant is set in the trendy Born district and is a study in industrial chic.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Trendy offerings from an El Bulli alum.

play.hed: 9 Best Places to Visit in Barcelona
play.dek: Sangria, shellfish, and triumphs of modern architecture—what's not to like?
play.seoTitle: 9 Best Places to Visit in Barcelona
play.seoDescription: Sangria, shellfish, and triumphs in modern architecture—what's not to like?
play.socialTitle: 9 Best Places to Visit in Barcelona
play.socialDescription: Sangria, shellfish, and triumphs in modern architecture—what's not to like?

items.title: [Casa Batlló](http://www.casabatllo.es/en/)
items.caption: Throw a stone in Barcelona, and chances are you'll hit something designed by Antoni Gaudí. Not that we would endorse throwing stones at modern architectural marvels, but the fact remains: it's more or less impossible to take in the sights in this city without it somehow involving Gaudí. Casa Batlló serves as the ideal crash course in the designer's oeuvre.

Casa Batlló was built between 1904 and 1906, and it’s the perfect example of Gaudí’s imaginative aesthetic. The colorful windows and sculptured ceilings give the house’s entrance a unique underwater feel, while the wavy walls, mosaics, and scale-like roof define the exterior. Visitors can stop by Casa Batlló any day of the year, from 9 AM to 9 PM (tickets available at [casabatllo.es](http://www.casabatllo.es/en/online-tickets/)).

items.title: [Park Güell](http://www.parkguell.cat/en/)
items.caption: If you have a free afternoon, we recommend making your way over to Park Güell after visiting Casa Batlló. Remember what we said about Gaudí being an inevitability in Barcelona? Prepare for a continuation in your world-class architecture crash course—he designed the mosaic-filled park, too.

Gaudí was heavily inspired by organic shapes and nature as he designed the park—just check out the giant salamander perched at the entrance. We suggest having Instagram at the ready to snap shots of everything this World Heritage Site has to offer, including the salmon-pink [Gaudí House Museum](http://www.casamuseugaudi.org/cm-eng/index.php).

items.title: [Papabubble](http://www.papabubble.com/)
items.caption: There's something about a trip to Papabubble that turns us into kids in a candy store––namely because, well, we are. Aside from offering treats in just about every flavor imaginable, the two Barcelona locations (one in the Gothic Quarter and one in Sarrià) also offer live candy shows, where you can see the magic-making process in person. So definitely stop by and pick up some sweet (pardon the pun) souvenirs to take back home with you.

items.title: El Born District
items.caption: The lower section of the La Ribera district, better known to the locals as El Born, is home to some of the best shopping and boutiques in the city. It's also home to your choice of incredibly fresh mojitos and very cheap, very delicious pizza. Once you've had your fill of modernist architecture, we recommend heading to El Born to view the lovely (and refreshingly simple) apartment fronts, shop all day, stay out all night, and grab a slice before finally going home.

items.title: [Museu Picasso](http://www.museupicasso.bcn.cat/en/)
items.caption: Housed in a series of gorgeous Medieval palaces in La Ribera, the eponymous Museu Picasso explores not only the life and career of Pablo, but also his time in Barcelona and the city's influence on his work. We're going to go out on a limb here and call this one a must-see. Check out the [museum’s website](http://www.bcn.cat/museupicasso/en/museum/times.html) for hours and ticket prices.

items.title: [W Barcelona](http://www.w-barcelona.com/)
items.caption: We'll be straight up: nothing quite compares to the beachfront view of the W Barcelona. Located right along the La Barceloneta boardwalk, you can step right outside the hotel, lounge on the famous Barcelona beach, and then explore the restaurants and clubs that are just steps away.

But really, there’s not much need to even leave the hotel at all. Once it's registered that, yes, you get to call this place home for the next few days, take advantage of their Michelin-starred chef's Bravo24 or take a dip in their Wet Deck pool, cocktail in hand.

items.title: [Fundació Joan Miró](http://www.fundaciomiro-bcn.org/?idioma=2)
items.caption: You can always brush up on your knowledge of the Surrealist movement at the [Dalí Theatre-Museum](http://www.salvador-dali.org/museus/teatre-museu-dali/en_index/), but what if you want to learn about the movement beyond the mustachioed genius? Pay a visit to Fundació Joan Miró, a Josep Lluís Sert-designed museum housed in Montjuïc.

While the space is primarily dedicated to the works of Joan Miró, the museum (an architectural gem in and of itself) is in no way exclusive. Keep your eye out for work by the likes of Magritte and Rothko, as well as special exhibitions dedicated to contemporary artists. Visit the [museum’s website](http://www.fundaciomiro-bcn.org/horari.php?idioma=2) for hours and ticket prices.

items.title: [Terraza Martinez](http://www.martinezbarcelona.com/)
items.caption: When in Spain, do as the Spanish do and partake heavily in authentic sangria and fresh, local seafood. Terraza Martinez is just the spot to do both––we especially like the cured tuna carpaccio, oysters, burrata, and rice dishes. The open terrace and unobstructed views of Barcelona are a lovely added bonus.

items.title: [La Sagrada Familia](http://www.sagradafamilia.cat/sf-eng/)
items.caption: Yup, it’s that Gaudí guy again. La Sagrada Familia is one of, if not THE most popular tourist attraction in the city, and it’s not hard to see why. Our advice for your visit: look up.

Aside from being one of the tallest churches in the world, with spires casting shadows on the city below, La Sagrada Familia’s interior is filled with stained glass and treelike columns that are worth witnessing (just be prepared to pay an [entrance fee](http://visit.sagradafamilia.cat/?lang=en)).

Would you believe us if we told you that his magnum opus is still a work in progress? One that isn't due to see completion until 2026, almost 100 years after his death? Keep in mind that when we say "work in progress," it's slightly different than that Ikea table that's been strewn across your living room floor, half-assembled, for a handful of days. Instead, the construction of this Catholic church was slowed by the impending Spanish Civil War, not just frustration and impossible-to-understand directions.

fields.name: The Coveteur
fields.shortBio: [The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture.
fields.bio:
[The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture. With an emphasis on highly personalized curation, The Coveteur goes one step further in examining the creative process, inspiration and influence of the individuals who are defining the zeitgeist of our times.

Founded by Stephanie Mark and Jake Rosenberg in 2011, The Coveteur pulls back the curtain on heretofore unseen adventures in style, travel, arts and culture and exposes what you’ve always wanted to see: an intimate and voyeuristic look at today's influencers.

play.hed: This Is the Barcelona Day Trip You Want to Go On
play.dek: For a day trip outside Barcelona, choose the ancient city of Tarragona over crowded and touristy Montserrat.
play.seoTitle: This Is the Barcelona Day Trip You Want to Go On
play.seoDescription: For a day trip outside Barcelona, choose the ancient city of Tarragona over crowded and touristy Montserrat.
play.socialTitle: This Is the Barcelona Day Trip You Want to Go On
play.socialDescription: For a day trip outside Barcelona, choose the ancient city of Tarragona over crowded and touristy Montserrat.
play.body:
[#image: /photos/53da9d9b6dec627b149f6e1e]|||Tarragona's Amphitheatre|||

Travelers to Barcelona are often seduced by the idea of an excursion to Montserrat, the multi-peaked mountain that is home to a famous Benedictine abbey and its legendary black Madonna relic. Though enchanting, Montserrat is almost always overrun with tourists and religious pilgrims, which makes the experience of visiting decidedly _un_spiritual. Instead, try the hour-long train ride to nearby Tarragona, a popular port city that also happens to be the former capital of an ancient Roman-controlled Spain (then called Tarraco) and a UNESCO World Heritage site rich with ancient remains. Archeologist Sonia Rohter and architect Bernat Carrau, both Barcelona residents and experts in their respective fields, present their top historic picks in the city.

[#image: /photos/53da9d9bdcd5888e145c0927]||||||

**Amphitheatre**







Tarragona’s 2nd century amphitheatre held close to 14,000 spectators in its heyday and was host to gory gladiator games and public executions. True to form, in 259, during Emperor Valerian’s persecution of the Christians, Tarragona’s Christian bishop Fructuosus and his two deacons were famously burned alive on its stage. Following the decline of the Roman empire and the subsequent rise of Christianity, the amphitheatre fell into disuse and two churches were built on the site–one Visigothic, and later, one Romanesque—likely to commemorate those eras. The foundations of these churches and the amphitheatre itself are remarkably well preserved, offering insight to the layers of the city’s history.



**Roman Walls**



Several sections of the city’s Roman walls are still intact. It’s thought that the majority of the walls were constructed at the end of the 3rd century BC, when the Roman Scipio brothers were using Tarragona as their base during the war against Hannibal and the Carthaginians; however, many phases of construction and modification have been identified. In fact, it’s now believed that the bases of these walls may even pre-date the Roman presence in the city. To fully experience the walls, stroll along the Passeig Arqueològic, a designated path around the perimeter of the old town flanked by the Roman walls.



**Tarragona Cathedral**



Tarragona may have a multitude of significant Roman ruins, but its medieval remains are equally enticing. Amid the narrow streets of the old town stands the impressive 12th century cathedral, which combines Romanesque and Gothic elements featuring a cloister and fountain. The cathedral is likely built upon an early Roman temple, and archeologists have been working to prove this hypothesis through geophysical survey.



**Pont del Diable**



The Pont del Diable, or Devil’s Bridge, is a Roman aqueduct (the Aqüeducte de les Ferreres)—which supplied water to Tarragona from the Francolí River—an example of the incredible Roman city planning reflected throughout the Roman empire. Like the amphitheatre, this aqueduct is well preserved and majestic, but is located 4 km from the city, so prepare for a short commute.







Trains to Tarragona depart frequently from Barcelona’s Sants train station and can be purchased in advance through Renfe, Spain’s national freight and passenger train company.



**More on Barcelona**



[Revitalized El Raval is the Barcelona Neighborhood You Don’t Want to Miss](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/02/barcelona-raval-revitalization)











[The Top 5 Vegetarian Restaurants in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/02/vegetarian-restaurant-guide-barcelona-spain)











[Like We Needed Another Reason to Visit: Prada Opens in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/11/prada-store-barcelona_slideshow_item0_1)

play.body:
[#image: /photos/53da96c96dec627b149f4db3]|||Hotel Sant Agustí in El Raval, Barcelona.|||

Few tourists venture down the narrow, crooked streets west of the Ramblas in Barcelona. Once the city’s gritty “Chinatown” red light district and the bohemian center of the city in the 1920s-30s, the neighborhood of El Raval has been undergoing a steady revitalization leading to today’s eclectic mix of medieval monasteries, avant-garde cultural centers, vibrant ethnic communities and hipster boutiques. On a recent stroll through the area with a group of historians and architects, we derived this list of our favorite spots for tracing history and soaking up the best of this diverse neighborhood.

[**Sant Pau del Camp**](http://webs.ono.com/santpaudelcamp/)



Overshadowed by the famed Sagrada Familia, Sant Pau del Camp — dating from the late 10th century — is actually the oldest church in the city. When the first stones were laid, the Raval was still outside the main city walls and surrounded by fields, hence its name: St. Paul of the Countryside. The church is one of the few examples of Romanesque architecture in the city. Of the most important architectural features, our experts note the beautiful medieval sculpture work on the western portal, the 12th century cloisters, and their arabesque arches where, if you look closely, you can see biblical scenes depicting Adam and Eve. _(101 Carrer de Sant Pau, open 10-1:30 pm and 4-7:30 pm, entrance fee for cloisters)_

[#image: /photos/53da96c9dcd5888e145be892]|||A game of street chess near the National Library


of Catalonia.|||

**[National Library of Catalonia](http://www.bnc.cat/eng) **



A splendid hideaway in the neighborhood is the vast courtyard of the National Library of Catalonia. A former medieval convalescent hospital started in 1401, it was one of Europe’s first hospital complexes and was the city’s main hospital until 1929. Today it is home to the National Library of Catalonia and the tranquil courtyard is open to the public. The quiet cafes hidden in the archways are a perfect place for a coffee break, while watching a life-sized “chess match.” At its northern end there are also displays on the history of the building and area. _(56 Carrer de l'Hospital)_

**Carrer de la Riera Baixa Vintage Shopping… and More**



Tucked away on a pedestrian passageway, the Carrer de la Riera Baixa might be the coolest street in Barcelona, or at least in El Raval. A vintage store mecca, you could spend hours digging through its many shops, but [Lailo](https://www.facebook.com/pages/Lailo-vintage-Barcelona/203161589710914) is the place to go for variety and quality. Other finds on the street might include military jackets, classic records, Art Deco statuettes, or if you’re feeling really adventurous, you can even become a real Barcelonan with a new hair cut or tattoo. _(between Carrer de l'Hospital and Carrer del Carme)_





[#image: /photos/53da96c9dcd5888e145be8a2]|||Children dancing at the CCCB.|||

**[Center of Contemporary Culture of Barcelona (CCCB)](http://www.cccb.org/en/ )**



It’s virtually impossible to not run into the white behemoth MACBA (Museu d'Art Contemporani de Barcelona) during your wanderings; however, keep going up the street and you’ll come to the Center of Contemporary Culture of Barcelona (CCCB). Located in part of the former Casa de Caritat almshouse built in 1802 and redesigned in the early 1990s by Helio Piñón and Albert Viaplana, the site is an interesting example of contrast. Today the center organizes exhibits, film screenings, lectures and public debates. Also, when you enter the courtyard — the mirrored wall will certainly catch your eye. Follow it to the top and you’ll be able to see the rooftops of the city and even the sea — a view you can only otherwise get from the top of Montjuic Mountain._ (5 Carrer Montalegre)_

[**Bar Casa Almirall**](https://www.facebook.com/secretsbarcelona/posts/286288821469784 )







Your ambling through the district will certainly merit finishing at one of El Raval’s historic cafes, such as the Casa Almirall. Once packed with artists, international writers and other free spirits during the area’s heyday in the 1920s and 30s, “The Admiral´s place” was opened in the 1860s and it still retains end-of-the-century modernista/art nouveau decor. The marble bar is especially beautiful, crowned with an elegant cast-iron muse from Barcelona's 1888 World's Fair. The walls are also decorated with posters of the various Exhibitions and other images from that era onward. Grab a seat and relax with a traditional vermuth, which they still serve with old-fashioned soda siphons, perhaps just like Hemingway had when he was in Barcelona. _(Carrer de Joaquín Costa, 33)_

miniGuides.dek: A maze of narrow, crooked streets, the barrio of El Born is a perfect microcosm of this vibrant city. Not only is the area centrally located, but it also tends to attract fewer crowds than the nearby Gothic Quarter and Las Rambla. Not that it’s any less atmospheric; indeed, the district has its own share of the city’s famously whimsical modernista architecture.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/549314970f6c91ef1e756868]|||
Explore the area's Catalan history at El Born Centre Cultural.
|||


##EXPLORE HERE

If you’re short on time, don’t even bother with the Picasso museum (the lines can get outrageously long, especially on Sunday, when the museum is free). Instead, head straight to the __[El Born Centre Cultural](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/el-born-centre-cultural)__ for a truly unique look at Catalan history. From the outside, it looks like an old market, which it was: The cast iron and glass Modernist structure was built in 1876 and was one of the first food markets built in this style. But inside you’ll find the archeological remains of 16th century Barcelona, giving you a glimpse of what life was like before the city was defeated in the Spanish War of Succession in 1714. 


##PLAY HERE

__[Palau de la Musica Catalana:](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/palau-de-la-m-sica-catalana)__ Catch a concert at the magical Palau de la Musica Catalana—if only to get a glimpse behind its doors. The awe-inspiring auditorium, built in 1908, is a [Modernista architectural jewel](http://www.contexttravel.com/city/barcelona/walking-tour-details/modernista-masterpieces-in-detail-sagrada-familia-and-hospital-de-sant-pau) designed by Gaudi contemporary Lluís Domènech i Montaner, its dreamlike interior a kaleidoscope of Art Nouveau stained-glass and mosaics. If you don’t have time for a concert, check the schedule for guided tours—and don’t forget to take a picture of its stunning stained glass ceiling. 
 
##EAT HERE

__[El Xampayet:](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/barcelona/el-xampanyet)__ has been serving its own brand of cava called “Xampanyet” (pronounced champanyet: an allusion to “champagne”) since 1929, along with artisanal draft beer and simple tapas of anchovies (among the city’s best), cheese, and local charcuterie. Join the locals crowding around the high marble tables in the front section– it’s the best spot to take in the lively atmosphere.

fields.name: Lily Heise of Context Travel
fields.shortBio: Lily Heise manages France and Spain for [Context Travel](http://www.contexttravel.com/), one of *Conde Nast Traveler*'s Top Travel Specialists.
fields.bio: Lily Heise manages France and Spain for [Context Travel](http://www.contexttravel.com/), one of *Conde Nast Traveler*'s Top Travel Specialists. Context offers small-group walking seminars in 24 of the world's cultural capitals, and is one of *Conde Nast Traveler*'s Top Travel Specialists. In addition to the seminars for intellectually curious travelers, Context is also a network of full-time professors and researches, scholars and specialists in disciplines including archaeology, art history, cuisine, urban planning, history, environmental science, and classics.

miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/5491feb9860c74c1162cb103]|||
The bright, colorful work of Barcelona artist Joan Miró is on view at Fundació Joan Miró.
|||








It’s easy to get carried away by the city’s storied Art Nouveau architecture, medieval alleyways and Mediterranean food, but to get a taste of everything, focus on three historic neighborhoods—Ciutat Vella, the Eixample, and Montjuïc—to experience the unique culture of Catalonia.


[#image: /photos/5492e366b6e03e8c2d0ce4fa]|||
Take a stroll through Barcoloneta, a waterfront area originally constructed in the 18th century.
|||





##Day 1: Ciutat Vella

Barcelona’s old city is made up mainly of the El Gotíc and El Raval neighborhoods. It’s worth spending a day wandering its narrow medieval streets.

__EAT__

After a day of walking Barcelona’s medieval quarter, stop into heavenly __[Caelum](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/barcelona/caelum)__ for some tea and pastries (grapefruit cakes and apple dumplings) made by local nuns. For an extra special treat, head to the basement to see the archaeological remains of the women’s baths of Barcelona. 

__PLAY__

Barcelona’s contemporary art museum, __[Museu d'Art Contemporani de Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/museu-d-art-contemporani-de-barcelona)__ (known as MACBA), focuses on mid-century abstraction and European Pop. Richard Meier designed the building—its glass exterior stands out against the mostly Gothic-style buildings in the area—in the Raval neighborhood, the city’s former red-light district, which has seen major revitalization since the early 90s. There’s no permanent collection, so even if you’ve been, it’s always worth another visit. 

Most modernista architecture can be found in the city’s Eixample district, but Gaudí’s __[Palau Güell](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/palau-g-ell)__, built for industrial tycoon Eusebi Güell (Gaudí’s friend and patron), is located in the Raval, just next to Las Ramblas. One of Gaudí’s early works, the Palau Güell is mixture of medieval and modern influences and is an ideal point from which to begin an exploration of Catalan modernism and the world of Gaudí.

__[Barceloneta](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/barceloneta)__, a neighborhood by the Barcelona port, was developed in the 18th century for city residents displaced by the construction of the nearby Ciudadela fortress. Wander its grid-like byways, keeping an eye out for the remaining two-story houses that originally lined its streets; or walk along the seaside promenade to admire the sculptures scattered along the beach.

__STAY__

__[Hotel Neri](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/spain/placa-de-catalunya/neri-hotel)__, a charming 4-star boutique hotel, is located just off the quiet Plaça Sant Felip Neri in the heart of the city’s former Jewish quarter, an easy walk from the sites of the *ciutat vella.* The hotel is housed in two former aristocratic palaces, one dating back to the 12th century. Its elegant, modern décor is a cool contrast to the property’s medieval stone walls (which are actually carved out of quartzite). 


[#image: /photos/5492e366860c74c1162cb3d6]|||
The restaurant at Hotel Omm serves traditional Catalan dishes—with a twist.
|||





##Day 2: The Eixample

Developed in the late 19th century as an alternative to the claustrophobic old city, this area (whose name is Catalan for “extension”) quickly became popular among the wealthy. Now its wide boulevards are home to luxury stores, trendy restaurants, and fantastical *modernista*buildings by Antoni Gaudí.

__EAT__

Patrons at __[Cerveceria Catalana](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/barcelona/cerveceria-catalana)__ usually spill out onto the wide Eixample street it faces. Locals love this place for its lively ambiance and creative food (we love the *montaditos Solomillo,*or open faced sandwich with beef). But it’s walk-ins only, so be prepared to join the queue snaking out front. 

__PLAY__

Designed in the early 20th century by architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner (a contemporary of Gaudí), __[Hospital de Sant Pau](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/hospital-de-sant-pau)__, together with Montaner’s Palau de la Música, is a UNESCO world heritage site and the world’s largest art nouveau site. Best of all, even though it’s just a few blocks away from the Sagrada Familia, it never seems to be overrun by tourists. 

__STAY__

Situated at the top of the Passeig de Gràcia, Barcelona’s *grand boulevard of modernista*architecture, the stunning __[Hotel Casa Fuster](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/spain/barcelona/hotel-casa-fuster--barcelona)__  is located in a 1908 building designed by renowned Catalan modernista architect Lluís Domènech i Montaner (he’s also behind the Palau de la Música Catalana and Hospital de Sant Pau). Don’t miss the hotel’s stylish rooftop bar and pool if you’re there in the summer. 

One of the first contemporary design hotels in Barcelona, [Hotel Omm](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/spain/barcelona/hotel-omm) opened in 2003 and is located in the city’s Eixample district among the fanciful turn of the century Modernista buildings. The simple rooms efficiently marry form with function, but it’s the facade, designed by architect Juli Capella, that’s most attention-grabbing, as its exterior seems to flap in the wind. Don’t skip the hotel’s gastronomic restaurant, Moo, which has a Michelin star and prepares Catalan food with a twist.




[#image: /photos/5492e36c860c74c1162cb3f9]|||
Sample old-school dishes at Bodega 1900, which specializes in recipes from a century ago. 
|||








##Day 3: Montjuïc Hill

This area offers a diverse history, stunning views of the Barcelona harbor, and plentiful cultural sites and museums, including an Olympic stadium. 

__EAT__

Run by the Quim family since 1914—its charming décor seemingly hasn’t changed much since—the popular __[Quimet y Quimet](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/barcelona/quimet-y-quimet)__ is known for serving tapas made with *conserves,*or high-quality canned ingredients, like salmon *montaditos*or canned sea urchin. Located in the up-and-coming Poble-Sec neighborhood, the tiny bodega is usually packed for the few hours it’s open, so be sure to arrive early if you want a space at one of its standing-only tables. 

If you can’t get a table at Tickets, the famed Adrià brothers’ newest gastronomic endeavor, try __[Bodega 1900](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/barcelona/bodega-1900)__ , Albert Adrià’s traditional vermutería. The restaurant serves dishes that were popular around 100 years ago, as well as a great selection of vermut. And although the focus isn’t on molecular gastronomy, you may find yourself face to face with Adrià’s famous liquid olives anyway. 

__PLAY__

Housed in the spectacular Palau Nacional of Montjuïc, which was built for the International Exposition of 1929, __[Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/museu-nacional-d-art-catalunya)__ presents an extensive collection of Catalan art, from Modernista sculptures to paintings by Casagemas, Fortuny, and Dalí. For those interested in exploring other genres of art, the museum also has large holdings of European Renaissance paintings and one of the best collections of Romanesque mural painting in the world. 

__[Fundació Joan Miró](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/barcelona/fundaci-joan-mir)__ pays homage to one of Catalonia’s best known artists, surrealist painter, sculptor, and ceramicist Joan Miró. The foundation was conceived by Miró himself to encourage other young contemporary artists, and now houses an extensive collection of the early- to mid- 20th century work of other famous artists (Calder, Rothko) in addition to that of its namesake.
miniGuides.seoDescription: A weekend is just enough time to see some of the best things that Barcelona has to offer: Its excellent cultural hot spots and museums, its gorgeous architecture, and its wonderful dining options.
miniGuides.socialDescription: A weekend is just enough time to see some of the best things that Barcelona has to offer: Its excellent cultural hot spots and museums, its gorgeous architecture, and its wonderful dining options.

fields.name: Sara McCarty, Context Travel
fields.shortBio: Sara McCarty is the France & Spain Manager at Context Travel.
fields.bio: Sara McCarty is the France & Spain Manager at Context Travel. Context is a network of scholars and specialists—in disciplines including archaeology, art history, cuisine, urban planning, history, environmental science, and classics—who, in addition to our normal work as professors and researchers, design and lead in-depth walking seminars for small groups of intellectually curious travelers. The Context vision is to bring together  local scholars and specialists with curious travelers to educate and impassion them; to allow them access to places and cultures that might otherwise remain out of site to the casual visitor; to invite them off the tourist track and into the real life of the people, history, and culture that makes these cities, destinations.

featuredShops.name: AOO
featuredShops.description: AOO is a design shop that offers both an in-house collection of pared-back wood furnishings and a curated selection of obscure everyday objects, plus housewares from established design brands like Hay and Another Country. For more information on the shop, check out [Barcelona's Most Charming Design Store](http://cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-12-01/aoo-barcelona-design-store).
featuredShops.shortDescription: The city's most charming design store.

featuredShops.name: Loewe
featuredShops.description: Loewe, across from the Mandarin Oriental on the Passeig de Gràcia, first opened its doors in Barcelona in 1910, and today it continues to offer exquisite leather goods for men and women, ranging from jackets and briefcases to handbags and wallets, and other superbly crafted accessories.

featuredShops.name: Bagués-­Masriera
featuredShops.description: One of the most striking of the Passeig's many jewelry stores is Bagués-­Masriera, founded by a Catalan family in 1839, offering precious stones and traditional and contemporary enameled jewelry in gold and silver.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Do your fine jewelry shopping here.

featuredShops.name: La Manual Alpargatera
featuredShops.description: This famous espadrille shop started out as a workshop and now serves star clients like Catherine Zeta Jones. The handmade shoes come in countless colours and styles and are great for walking over cobblestones. They also pack very neatly, one shoe hugging the other. “It’s where you go for espadrilles in every size, style, and color under the sun,” says fashion editor Eugenia Santiesteban Soto. “They’ll customize a special color, help you choose among different fabrics—from canvas to leather—and let you pick a ribbon trim. Then they trace your foot and custom-fit the size.” Made-to-order espadrilles take 15 days on average.

featuredShops.name: L'Illa Diagonal
featuredShops.description: This stylish complex in an upscale neighborhood in the middle of the city is filled mostly with small shops but also houses one of the city's two FNAC stores, a ZARA, a Decathalon offering all sorts of outdoor and sporting products, and Spanish designer Purificacíon García.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Don't call this stylish complex a mall.

related.hed: Delpozo's Creative Director on the Best of Barcelona
related.dek: Josep Font, the creative director behind heritage brand Delpozo, may live in Madrid but he’s from Barcelona. Who better to show us around?

items.caption: Josep Font, who trained as an architect, launched his own ready-to-wear line in 1991—moving first to Tokyo, later to Paris, and finally back home to Barcelona, and becoming the rare breakout Spanish designer with both French approval and global reach. When he was tapped to revive the Spanish fashion house Delpozo in 2012, Font left his hometown for the capital, but he returns every other month to visit family and friends and to draw inspiration. Here, he shares his photos of the place he considers the most beautiful city in the world.

items.title: The Gaudí You Shouldn't Miss
items.caption: "People have told me that my work reminds them of Gaudí, the way I use volume and form. This makes sense—I’m a huge fan of the architect, and his La Pedrera is one of my favorite buildings. It’s inspired by organic shapes found in nature, and for me, it’s a great example of creative freedom. I always visit early in the day, before it gets hot and crowded."

items.title: A Drink With History
items.caption: “Bar Muy Buenas is my favorite place to have a late-afternoon aperitif. It’s located in the Raval, one of the city’s oldest neighborhoods. The building dates back to 1896, and the interior has these spectacular Art Nouveau wood-and-glass panels.”

items.title: The Good-Looking Theme Park
items.caption: “Tibidabo is the oldest amusement park in Spain. We used to go when I was a boy. My brother adored it, but I didn’t. It was just too much—the colors, the heights—I was scared! Now I love it. It’s on the highest peak of the Collserola Mountain Range, and the views from there are beautiful: You can look out over Barcelona all the way to the sea, and at night, a monastery on the mountain is lit up—it’s amazing.”

items.title: The Culture Club
items.caption: "“The Design Hub, a huge building that houses the Barcelona Design Museum, just opened in the city’s Glòries district—right by the Torre Agbar, an amazing bullet-shaped, rainbow-colored skyscraper. It’s cool to see how a building can change a neighborhood: People actually come to this part of town now, and the Hub is getting great exhibits. There’s a fashion photography retrospective opening this fall that I’m really excited to check out.”

items.title: Cutting-Edge Classical
items.caption: "Casa Beethoven is a little sheet music store on Las Ramblas that doubles as a performance space. As a child I was forced to play the organ for five years. I didn’t play well at all. Now that I don’t have to play, I love to hear live music. All of the musicians who perform here are unknown, but that’s the interesting part—young artists getting a chance to showcase their talent.”

items.title: Old Men and the Sea
items.caption: “One of the things I miss most is the water. I love taking long walks on La Barceloneta beach. It still has that air of old Barcelona—almost like a small fishing village: the way the locals dress, the tiny cafés, the restaurants that’ve been there for ages. If you visit very early in the morning, you can see the old fishermen returning with their catch.”

items.title: The Home (Away From Home) Cooked Meal
items.caption: “I always have friends meet me at La Cuina d’en Garriga when I’m in town. It’s family-owned and part Mediterranean restaurant, part shop that sells meat, fish, vegetables, and wonderful pastas. The owners really care about the cooking, and the service is excellent. It all feels very homey and spontaneous, as if it were my own kitchen.”

related.body:
[#image: /photos/53da89b46dec627b149f12c6]||||||

As if its [delicious food](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/02/vegetarian-restaurant-guide-barcelona-spain) and [brilliant architecture](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/06/cities-architecture-design-lovers-photos_slideshow_Gaud-s-Art-Nouveau_7) weren't enough incentive to visit Barcelona: A brand new Prada store has just opened up, just a few steps away from Gaudí’s La Pedrera.



It's not just any store—it was designed by the acclaimed [Roberto Baciocchi](http://www.baciocchi.it/site.php?lang=eng&lg=en), drawing architecture buffs as well as fashionistas—and is one of Prada's largest European shops, sprawled across 1600 square meters. It's also beautiful, decked out in black marble and mirror, with palladium and glass cabinetry throughout. It will carry the brand's ready-to-wear womenswear, menswear, footwear, and accessories lines, and will also feature a dedicated area for Prada's [Made to Measure project](http://www.prada.com/en/made-to-measure)—an exclusive service for clients requesting custom-fit products.



The store joins fellow high fashion labels Gucci and Chanel on the city's shopping hub, Passeo de Gracia. While you're in the neighborhood, also check out cool boutiques like [Sabater Hnos](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/11/souvenirs-soap-barcelona-sabater-hnos-shopping), or stop by the local hotspot [Granja Lido](http://www.cntraveler.com/iconic-trips/2012/08/barcelona-girona-travel-tourism-hotels-accomodations-restaurants-trips) for some hazelnut-breaded croquettes._ (88 Paseo de Gracia; +34 934 19 3641, [www.prada.com](http://cms.cntraveler.com/cf#/content/cntraveler/daily-traveler/2013/11/prada-store-barcelona.html))_










**More on Barcelona:**



[Five Perfect Days in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/iconic-trips/2012/08/barcelona-girona-travel-tourism-hotels-accomodations-restaurants-trips)







[Things to Do and See in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/05/barcelona-instagram-photo-tour_slideshow)







[Great Dates in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/features/honeymoons-romantic-trips/2012/02/dates-arts-culture)

related.hed: Beyond Barcelona: 7 Spanish Destinations to Visit This Summer
related.dek: Barcelona's mayor wants [to cap the number of tourists](http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/spain/11643802/Incoming-Barcelona-mayor-wants-to-introduce-tourist-cap.html) in the city. But that doesn't mean you should cancel those plane tickets you bought—use the trip to check out these other Spanish spots instead.

items.title: Seville
items.caption:
__Why You Should Go:__ Seville is hot again thanks to a design-heavy renovation of its downtown. There's great shopping, cool architecture (such as "The Mushrooms," pictured here), and art galleries like the elegant white-on-white Delimbo.

__Read More:__ [The Rebirth of Historic Seville](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-25/the-rebirth-of-historic-seville)

items.title: San Sebastian
items.caption:
__Why You Should Go:__ Spain's Basque country is beautiful, and its pinxto (tapas) bar scene guarantees your choice of incredible bites: beef cheeks, squid ink risotto, and suckling pig are just some of the local specialties.

__Read More:__ [10 Can't-Miss Pinxto Bars in San Sebastian](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-03-26/10-cant-miss-pintxos-bars-in-san-sebastian-spain)

items.title: Segovia
items.caption:
__Why You Should Go:__ Perfect for a day or weekend trip, picturesque Segovia has many layers of history—you can see the ruins of a Roman aqueduct, a Moorish alcazar, and Europe's very last Gothic cathedral—all in one place. 

__Read More:__ [5 Reasons to Skip Toledo and Head to Segovia](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-05-04/segovia-madrid-spain-excursion-guide)

items.title: San Lorenzo de El Escorial
items.caption:
__Why You Should Go:__ About an hour northwest of Madrid, nestled in the Guadarrama mountain range, is this UNESCO-listed small town chock full of gorgeous architecture, most notably the San Lorenzo de El Escorial library (pictured) and monastery. 

__Read More:__ [10 of the World's Most Beautiful Libraries](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-09-02/10-of-the-worlds-most-beautiful-libraries/10)

items.title: Ibiza
items.caption:
__Why You Should Go:__ Although it gets a reputation for being full of club kids, locals know how to find pristine, quiet beaches, especially during the off season. 

__Read More:__ [Ibiza for Grown-Ups](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2013-06-10/photos-ibiza-holiday-hotels-clubs-beaches)

items.title: Navarra
items.caption:
__Why You Should Go:__ Its emerging food scene is beginning to rival those in Madrid and Barcelona. The food scene also quite vegetarian-friendly, with a focus on ingredients like beans, artichokes, lettuce hearts, and piquillo peppers.

__Read More:__ [Navarra, Spain's Next Great Food Scene](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-04-21/navarra-spain-next-great-food-scene)

items.title: Madrid
items.caption:
__Why You Should Go:__ Spain's capital gets an undeserved reputation as Barcelona's shyer, stodgier cousin. But the city is full of world-class art and green space, much of which (like Retiro Park, pictured here) is free to the public.

__Read More:__ [10 Best Free Things to Do in Madrid](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2015-03-17/10-best-free-things-to-do-in-madrid/)
