Lilit's favorite destinations include Lisbon, Tel Aviv, Nashville, and Mexico City. Her work has also appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Glamour, The Guardian, Cosmopolitan, and The New York Observer.

related.hed: 15 Minutes Inside Barcelona's Busiest Tapas Bar
related.dek: At Quimet y Quimet, a tiny, standing-room only establishment, not much has changed in its more than 100 years of service.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/558196e33a5d79a77fccce7e]||||||





At 6:48 p.m. on a balmy Barcelona evening, a line of more than 15 people has formed outside an otherwise inconspicuous red doorway in the El Poble-sec district. A rectangular sign sways gently overhead, but its lettering is small enough to leave passersby squinting and wondering, slowing their gait and murmuring to each other, *“¿Qué esta pasando aquí?"*(What’s happening here?)

Twelve minutes later, a man opens the doors, steps onto the street to survey the growing crowd and smiles broadly, moving his arm in a sweeping motion—the universal symbol for *welcome.*Bespectacled and black-clad, this man could be any of the regular guys throughout the city, were it not for his notoriety as one of its most revered culinary creators. The crowd, you see, is here for him. Joaquim (“Quim”) Pérez is the fourth-generation proprietor of Quimet y Quimet, a space that fits approximately 15 to 20 people, standing. Quim’s great-grandfather opened the shop in 1914 as a place to sell his homemade wine, but since then it's established a reputation as the city’s best tapas bar. 

Once inside, customers divide and conquer the limited space available: a stainless steel bar, small tables on either side of the room, a counter surface at the back, and everywhere in between. The room is lined with wine and alcohol bottles, and has stacks of high-quality canned Spanish *conservas*(seafood and meats) that are the backbone of Quim’s many creations. A tile illustration in Spanish shows a policeman giving recommendations for the city: “Gaudí, Picasso, Miró…” he says, while a tourist replies, “First things first, Quimet y Quimet!”

Pressed together, customers peruse unadorned laminated menus and choose from more than 30 combinations of tapas and 30 types of *montaditos,*the small, open-faced canapé-like edibles that the bar is best known for. From his perch behind a glass counter, Quim deftly scans the crowd to make eye contact with anyone ready to order, repeating the requests and calling out for ingredients from the coworker next to him. Tabs are also maintained by Quim, who scribbles additions on a small notepad in between making small talk with patrons and preparing orders. He grabs a small, white plate from the shelf behind him and begins to build, delivering orders in 30 seconds or less.  If you ask nicely, he might even create something that’s not on the menu.

“What do you think is best here?” asks a man who has pushed himself to the bar. 

Quim pauses. “Everything.” Laughter scatters across the crowd, and Quim smiles. The man is still waiting. 

Quim leans forward and tries again. “Do you like mussels?”

*Chipirones,*or stuffed baby squid, arrive, as do house red wine and a montadito with anchovy, baked red pepper, tomato relish, and olive; another comes with firm tuna belly and soft orange sea urchin. Another order yields a montadito with a creamy slab of Brie, sweet red pepper, artichoke, and caviar, while one of the house specialties—salmon atop Greek yogurt and generously draped with truffle honey—is an unexpectedly delicious combination of sweet and fresh, soft and crunchy. Each piece of crisp, toasted bread is piled nearly two inches high with ingredients, and it’s inevitable you’ll lose some in the battle to bite. 


[#image: /photos/558197e3eb260e510b3ae0ed]||||||



There is a lull in ordering, and Quim wipes down the counter and peers over the bar and out the door. “Tenemos espacio adentro,” he gestures to the line of people who have curled around the building and crowded the doorway to watch and wait. “Move in,” he encourages. “There is space.”

After a final montadito with sweet tomato and cured wisps of beef, it’s time for the tab. “Nothing else?” asks Quim. “No?” The bill is settled, and the chef bows his head slightly in thanks. With that, he returns to a ritual he performs hundreds of times a night: he grabs a plate, and begins to build.

shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53da89b46dec627b149f12c6]||||||

As if its [delicious food](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/02/vegetarian-restaurant-guide-barcelona-spain) and [brilliant architecture](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/06/cities-architecture-design-lovers-photos_slideshow_Gaud-s-Art-Nouveau_7) weren't enough incentive to visit Barcelona: A brand new Prada store has just opened up, just a few steps away from Gaudí’s La Pedrera.



It's not just any store—it was designed by the acclaimed [Roberto Baciocchi](http://www.baciocchi.it/site.php?lang=eng&lg=en), drawing architecture buffs as well as fashionistas—and is one of Prada's largest European shops, sprawled across 1600 square meters. It's also beautiful, decked out in black marble and mirror, with palladium and glass cabinetry throughout. It will carry the brand's ready-to-wear womenswear, menswear, footwear, and accessories lines, and will also feature a dedicated area for Prada's [Made to Measure project](http://www.prada.com/en/made-to-measure)—an exclusive service for clients requesting custom-fit products.



The store joins fellow high fashion labels Gucci and Chanel on the city's shopping hub, Passeo de Gracia. While you're in the neighborhood, also check out cool boutiques like [Sabater Hnos](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/11/souvenirs-soap-barcelona-sabater-hnos-shopping), or stop by the local hotspot [Granja Lido](http://www.cntraveler.com/iconic-trips/2012/08/barcelona-girona-travel-tourism-hotels-accomodations-restaurants-trips) for some hazelnut-breaded croquettes._ (88 Paseo de Gracia; +34 934 19 3641, [www.prada.com](http://cms.cntraveler.com/cf#/content/cntraveler/daily-traveler/2013/11/prada-store-barcelona.html))_










**More on Barcelona:**



[Five Perfect Days in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/iconic-trips/2012/08/barcelona-girona-travel-tourism-hotels-accomodations-restaurants-trips)







[Things to Do and See in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/05/barcelona-instagram-photo-tour_slideshow)







[Great Dates in Barcelona](http://www.cntraveler.com/features/honeymoons-romantic-trips/2012/02/dates-arts-culture)

shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d0326dec627b149d70b4]||||||

I don't usually buy beauty products as souvenirs (they're messy and take up too much space in my bag), but I spent a solid 45 minutes browsing and sniffing at [Sabater Hnos](http://www.shnos.com.ar/), a soap boutique off of Barcelona's quiet Plaza de Sant Felip Neri. Third generation soap-makers (a trio of siblings, with some help from dad) run the company, which makes every color and shape and scent of solid soaps imaginable.







 

[#image: /photos/53d9d0326dec627b149d70b2]||||||

I saw piles of confetti-shaped shreds you'd think were cupcake sprinkles; Lego-like stick figures holding hands called _parejitas_ (that's lovebirds); and, my favorite, delicate slices of soaps that look like rose petals. I stocked up on gift boxes of those for hostess presents…but I might just end up keeping them for myself.
shop.dek: Third-generation soap makers operate Sabater Hnos., a small boutique in Barcelona. The handcrafted soaps, which come in a variety of shapes and colors and scents, make perfect souvenirs or gifts.

shop.hed: AOO: Barcelona's Most Charming Design Store
shop.dek: Nestled between Barcelona’s hip Gracia neighborhood and its tony shopping avenue Paseo de Gracia is a small street called Sèneca that’s becoming something of a mini design destination. In addition to the gallery Miquel Alzueta, the vintage furniture shop OX, and the tailormade shoe salon Cuervo, it’s home to the city’s most charming contemporary design store: [AOO](http://cntraveler.com/shops/barcelona/aoo). Here's a look inside.

items.caption: Opened last fall by furniture designer Marc Morro, creative director Oriol Villar, and graphic designer Clara Quintana, [AOO](http://cntraveler.com/shops/barcelona/aoo) offers both an in-house collection of pared-back wood furnishings and a selection of obscure everyday objects sourced by Morro, like artisanal Japanese kitchen tools and a set of knives from a small village in Mallorca. In addition, the AOO team cherry-picks relevant housewares from established design brands like Hay and Another Country that aren’t sold elsewhere in Barcelona. It all falls under the shop’s playful mission statement, to be “a place where you can easily find things that are hard to find.”

Inside AOO, furniture and housewares are artfully stacked on stepped platforms and one another. All of the wooden furniture pictured here belongs to the store’s own collection — which is designed and made in house — while the accessories span everything from Weck jars, to baskets and tea strainers made by an artisan in Kyoto, to the yellow stool at center, which is by the London designer Martino Gamper.
The entrance to AOO, which is housed in a small former garage on Barcelona’s Sèneca street. The shop was designed by the local architecture firm Arquitectura-G.

Among the offerings in AOO’s spartan in-house furniture collection is the Cadireta chair, whose name means “little chair” in Catalan. Morro not only designed the low-slung seat, but crafts them himself out of pine in AOO’s wood workshop, which is located in Barcelona’s industrial Poblenou neighborhood.

Morro also makes the store’s Tripos stools, which come in pine, beech, or oak and are pictured here in AOO’s workshop. (He happens to be something of a stool aficionado, in fact — he has a collection of more than 25 different stools at home.)

The Tripos stools on display at AOO, along with Enzo Mari’s classic Formosa calendar, a series of orange chairs designed by Arquitectura-G, and another wood stool, in the upper left corner, that was designed by Morro and featured in the Spanish Pavilion at the 2014 Venice Architecture Biennale.

The store has several cabinets that feature all kinds of small design items and everyday objects that the AOO team happens to love: bowls by the Viennese design duo Mischer-Traxler, a wooden computer keyboard by Orée, the Mallorcan knives, pepper grinders by Ettore Sottsass, and below them, dishes by the UK heritage brand Falcon Enamelware.

The store has several cabinets that feature all kinds of small design items and everyday objects that the AOO team happens to love: bowls by the Viennese design duo Mischer-Traxler, a wooden computer keyboard by Orée, the Mallorcan knives, pepper grinders by Ettore Sottsass, and below them, dishes by the UK heritage brand Falcon Enamelware.
The AOO team recently reissued another of Milá’s classic designs themselves: the wicker Salvador chair, which is now produced for the store by hand in a workshop in Valencia.

The Pepitu is a classic folding chair designed by Morro and named after Villar’s grandfather, a carpenter who once made seats similar to this one. AOO’s version is made of beechwood and a linen fabric sourced from a small textile workshop in Mallorca, where Morro is from.

The store’s Normales collection is a series of basics made from pine plywood: storage bins, a small shelf, a tool caddy, a cord manager, and a box that can be used as either a stool, an ottoman, or a side table depending on one’s needs.
Quintana and Morro in front of AOO.

shop.seoDescription: Opened by furniture designer Marc Morro, creative director Oriol Villar, and graphic designer Clara Quintana, AOO offers wood furnishings and obscure everyday objects.
shop.seoTitle: AOO: Barcelona's Most Charming Design Store
shop.socialDescription: Located in Barcelona’s hip Gracia neighborhood, AOO aims to be a place where you can easily find things that are hard to find.

memberComments.comment: "Beautiful hotel and amazing staff! Impressed from the minute I arrived. Spacious rooms, beautiful decor, great restaurants, and the service was outstanding. The best hotel in Spain, without a doubt."
"One of my favorites of all time. You feel like you are in another time period."
"The only place to stay in Seville! The staff is superb, the bar wonderful, the breakfast buffet amazing, and the facilities sublime."

Having been to Barcelona numerous times for business, I'm glad I finally decided to go to the Hotel 1898. I won't stay anywhere else now. The location is excellent, right off La Ramblas; the rooms are spacious; the service is great and it's all very comfortable.
Still cannot believe it was a cigar factory. The spa and pool area are the best in the city.
Excellent location on Passeig de Gràcia near Gaudi's Casa Batlló - wonderful, modern interiors by Spanish designer Patricia Urqulola.
Would stay again in a heartbeat.
"Excellent hotel, services, food—everything here is great! The view of the city from the Roof Bar is beautiful!"
Superb location. Grand architecture and views, though some rooms are much better than others (we asked to move).
Amazing city, great hotel. Good location.

Excellent location near center of culture, museums, dining. Close to train station with easy connections to S. Spain. Spacious well appointed rooms with heavy blackout drapes-so great when you're coming from an international flight. Beautiful old world ambiance!
A relaxing haven in the midst of Madrid. Decadent suites, and the restaurant's old domed glass ceiling just has to be seen. Great for anything from brunch to late-night drinks.
"AC hotels are wonderful just for the very fact that everything in the mini fridge is included with your stay, and they refill each day."

featuredStays.name: Casa Camper Barcelona
featuredStays.description: Camper, the hip Mallorca-based shoe company that’s built a reputation on a homely look and progressive environmental image, has a hit on its hands with its first hotel, a 25-room New Age inn made from a renovated nineteenth-century commercial building in Barcelona’s trendy El Raval quarter. Casa Camper delivers on its parent company’s feel-good dogma with clean, comfortable, ever-so-slightly austere rooms that have separate sleeping and living spaces. Walls are painted red, beds are made up in quality white cottons, and furniture runs to the functional. There’s a great roof terrace with hammocks for a quick siesta, bicycles are available to rent, and a free 24/7 snack bar serves fresh fruit, sandwiches, soup, desserts, green tea, and mineral water. Best of all, rooms are a great buy in this pricey city.
featuredStays.shortDescription: A shoe company designs a hip hotel.

featuredStays.name: Mandarin Oriental, Barcelona
featuredStays.description: The location of this former bank headquarters, which opened as a hotel at the end of 2009 on "the lovely Passeig de Gràcia," ensures that "guests can easily stroll to restaurants and shopping." The "very contemporary and modern room design" by Spaniard Patricia Urquiola mixes leather and velvet upholstery with a palette of green, black, and gold. Relax in a Scandinavian-style armchair and dine on authentic Catalan cuisine at Moments restaurant, or visit Banker’s Bar to sip cocktails in a venue reminiscent of a gentlemen’s club.

featuredStays.name: Hotel Mercer, Barcelona
featuredStays.description: One block in from the old Roman walls, a refined retreat in the heart of the Gothic Quarter.
featuredStays.shortDescription: A rarefied retreat in the Gothic Quarter.

featuredStays.name: Majestic Hotel & Spa
featuredStays.description: Located at Passeig de Gràcia in the heart of Barcelona, this 5-star luxury hotel is close to tourist attractions including Las Ramblas, the Gaudi-designed church of Sagrada Familia, and Plaza de Cataluña. The hotel has 275 rooms, which were refurbished in 2012, as well as 28 apartments. The swimming pool and cocktail bar, both located on the rooftop, offer visitors views of the city, and the hotel’s services include a luxury spa, a multilingual staff, on-call medical staff, and babysitting services upon request.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Five-star luxury in the heart of the city.

featuredStays.name: W Barcelona

featuredStays.description: This beachfront gem was designed by Ricardo Bofill.
